bibl.title: I.E. Spafford v. Territory of Washington King County. Petition for Writ
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: District Court of the Third Judicial District of Washington Territory, holding terms at Seattle

body.p: Territory of Washington,) Third Judicial District.) ss.
In the District Court holding terms at Seattle.
In the matter of the application of I.E. Spafford for a writ of Habeas Corpus.
To the Hon. Richard A. Jones of the above entitled District Court:
The petition of I.E. Spafford respectfully shows to wit your Honor,
1. That he is now imprisoned and restrained of his liberty by William Cochrane, Sheriff of King County, in the jail of said County, at the City of Seattle.

2. That your petitioner is not committed or detained upon process issued on any final judgement of a Court of competent jurisdiction nor for any contempt of any Court, officer or body having authority in the premises to commit; nor upon a warrant issued from the District Court upon an indictment or information.

3. That the cause or pretense of the restraint according to the best of the petitioner's knowledge and belief, is by virtue of a certain Writ of committment issued by one R.C. Portway, a Justice of the Peace in and for said King County, on the 29th day of March, 1887, reciting and commanding as follows: "Whereas, at a Justice's Court this day held at my office, in said County, for the examination of I.E. Spafford for the alleged offense of having on said Mch. 22, 1887, in said County, feloniously administered a certain dangerous and deleterious drug to one Fanse Spafford, then and there being pregnant with a quick child, with the intent and for the purpose of causing an abortion and destroy such child, the said administration not having been necessary to save the life of said mother, whereby and for the reason of said administration the siad Fanse Spafford did die, and upon arraingement of said defendant for said alleged offense, the said defedant did walve examination, and being by me adjudged to give bail in the sum of $500 for his appearance at the next term of the District Court to be held at Seattle, is said County on the last Monday in May, 1887, and the defendant having refused and failed to furnish said bonds, it was adjudged and ordered that he be committed to the jail of said County until he be discharged by law. Therefore, you the said Constable and keeper of the jail are commanded him the said I.E. Spafford to take into custody and safely keep until he furnish said bonds, or until he shall thence be discharged by due course of law."

4. That said imprisonment and restraint of your petitioner is illegal; and such illegality consists in this: That your petitioner is not guilty of the offense charged against him in said writ, or any offense, and there is no probable
cause to believe him to be guilty of said offense, or guilty of any criminal act wharever.

That the petitioner waived an examination as alleged in said writ, but did so only because he was then without an attorney to assist him, and had no competent legal adviser, and was ignorant of his rights and the effect and consequences of waiving an examination; and was induced to waive an examination at that time by persons who represented that if the examination should then be waived your petitioner could afterwards have a fairer examination at Seattle.
Wherefore, your petitioner prays that a Writ of Habeas Corpus to inquire into the cause of said imprisonment, and for his discharge from the custody of said Sheriff.
Greene, Hanford + McGraw Attorneys for Petitioner.
